Lp spaces, monotone functions

Let fn ⁣:[0,1]→[0,∞)\func{f_n}{\br{0,1}}{\pco{0,\infty}}fn​:[0,1]→[0,∞) be a sequence of functions, each of which is non-decreasing on the interval [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]. Suppose the sequence is uniformly bounded in L2([0,1])L^2\p{\br{0,1}}L2([0,1]). Show that there exists a subsequence that converges in L1([0,1])L^1\p{\br{0,1}}L1([0,1]).
Solution.

Let M=sup⁡n∥fn∥L2M = \sup_n \norm{f_n}_{L^2}M=supn​∥fn​∥L2​. For t∈[0,1)t \in \pco{0, 1}t∈[0,1), Cauchy-Schwarz gives

fn(t)(1−t)≤∫t1fn(x) dx≤∥fn∥L21−tfn(t)≤M1−t.\begin{gathered} f_n\p{t}\p{1 - t} \leq \int_t^1 f_n\p{x} \,\diff{x} \leq \norm{f_n}_{L^2} \sqrt{1 - t} \\ f_n\p{t} \leq \frac{M}{\sqrt{1 - t}}. \end{gathered}fn​(t)(1−t)≤∫t1​fn​(x)dx≤∥fn​∥L2​1−t​fn​(t)≤1−t​M​.​

Hence, for a fixed t∈[0,1)t \in \pco{0, 1}t∈[0,1), {fn(t)}n\set{f_n\p{t}}_n{fn​(t)}n​ is a bounded sequence in R\RR, and so it admits a convergent subsequence. By a diagonal argument, we get a subsequence {fnk}k\set{f_{n_k}}_k{fnk​​}k​ which converges pointwise for each q∈[0,1]∩Qq \in \br{0, 1} \cap \Qq∈[0,1]∩Q.

We will show that this subsequence converges almost everywhere. For q∈[0,1]∩Qq \in \br{0, 1} \cap \Qq∈[0,1]∩Q, set f(q)=lim⁡k→∞fnk(q)f\p{q} = \lim_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{q}f(q)=limk→∞​fnk​​(q). Observe that if q<rq < rq<r are rationals, then

fnk(q)≤fnk(r)  ⟹  f(q)≤f(r)f_{n_k}\p{q} \leq f_{n_k}\p{r} \implies f\p{q} \leq f\p{r}fnk​​(q)≤fnk​​(r)⟹f(q)≤f(r)

by taking k→∞k \to \inftyk→∞. For any x∈[0,1]x \in \br{0, 1}x∈[0,1], set Lx=sup⁡q<xf(q)L_x = \sup_{q < x}{f\p{q}}Lx​=supq<x​f(q) and Ux=inf⁡x<qf(q)U_x = \inf_{x < q}{f\p{q}}Ux​=infx<q​f(q). Then if x<yx < yx<y, there exists q∈(x,y)q \in \p{x, y}q∈(x,y) which implies Ux≤f(q)≤LyU_x \leq f\p{q} \leq L_yUx​≤f(q)≤Ly​ and so (Lx,Ux)∩(Ly,Uy)=∅\p{L_x, U_x} \cap \p{L_y, U_y} = \emptyset(Lx​,Ux​)∩(Ly​,Uy​)=∅. Since [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] is separable, there can only be countably many disjoint non-trivial intervals, and so Lx=UxL_x = U_xLx​=Ux​ for almost every x∈[0,1]x \in \br{0, 1}x∈[0,1]. For such an xxx, let q,rq, rq,r be rational such that q≤x≤rq \leq x \leq rq≤x≤r and so

fnk(q)≤fnk(x)≤fnk(r)f(q)≤lim inf⁡k→∞fnk(x)≤lim sup⁡k→∞fnk(x)≤f(r).\begin{gathered} f_{n_k}\p{q} \leq f_{n_k}\p{x} \leq f_{n_k}\p{r} \\ f\p{q} \leq \liminf_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{x} \leq \limsup_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{x} \leq f\p{r}. \end{gathered}fnk​​(q)≤fnk​​(x)≤fnk​​(r)f(q)≤k→∞liminf​fnk​​(x)≤k→∞limsup​fnk​​(x)≤f(r).​

Taking the supremum over qqq and infimum over rrr, we see

Lx≤lim inf⁡k→∞fnk(x)≤lim sup⁡k→∞fnk(x)≤Ux,L_x \leq \liminf_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{x} \leq \limsup_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{x} \leq U_x,Lx​≤k→∞liminf​fnk​​(x)≤k→∞limsup​fnk​​(x)≤Ux​,

so these are actually all equalities, which means lim⁡k→∞fnk(x)=Lx=Ux\lim_{k\to\infty} f_{n_k}\p{x} = L_x = U_xlimk→∞​fnk​​(x)=Lx​=Ux​. Thus, fnkf_{n_k}fnk​​ converges for almost every x∈[0,1]x \in \br{0, 1}x∈[0,1].

To complete the proof, we established earlier that 0≤fn(t)≤M1−t∈L1([0,1])0 \leq f_n\p{t} \leq \frac{M}{\sqrt{1 - t}} \in L^1\p{\br{0,1}}0≤fn​(t)≤1−t​M​∈L1([0,1]), so by dominated convergence, fnk→ff_{n_k} \to ffnk​​→f in L1L^1L1.
